title-group.article-title: Micromechanical Modeling of Fracture Energy for Hooked-End Steel Fiber-Reinforced Cementitious Composites

article-meta.aff: 1Key Laboratory of Advance Civil Engineering Materials of the Ministry of Education, Tongji University, Shanghai 20092, P.R. China
2Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, University of California, Los Angeles, CA 90095, USA

abstract.p: Since pullout behaviors of fibers intersecting a fracture plane of cementitious composite are similar to those in a single-fiber pullout test, micromechanical model of fracture energy for hooked-end steel fiber-reinforced cementitious composite (HSFRCC) is developed on the basis of single hooked-end steel fiber pullout test. The hooked-ends of steel fibers intersecting a fracture plane have various deformations which can be generally classified into hooked-end total deformation, partial deformation, and nondeformation. The pullout energy of steel fiber with deformed hooked-end is significantly different from that with nondeformed one; derivations of pullout energies of hooked-end steel fibers with deformed/nondeformed hooked-ends are carried out first. The fracture energy model of HSFRCC is proposed using probabilistic method accounting for energy contributions from all steel fibers intersecting the fracture plane. Experimental validation of the proposed micromechanical model is performed, and excellent agreements are observed in comparison with experimental data from uniaxial tensile tests. As the proposed fracture energy model is a function of physical and micro-geometric properties of hooked-end steel fibers and cementitious matrix, it can guide optimal design of HSFRCC.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Steel fibers were first proposed as dispersed reinforcements for concrete in 1960s (Brandt, 2008). During the past several decades, steel fiber-reinforced cementitious composites (SFRCC) have been extensively studied, considerably developed, and popularly adopted in engineering practices (Shaaban and Gesund, 1993; Song and Hwang, 2004; Ramadoss and Nagamani, 2006; Thomas and Ramaswamy, 2007). One of the most important benefits of incorporating steel fibers into cementitious composites is the significant enhancement on energy absorption during structural cracking. Fracture energy as one of the entities used for evaluating energy absorption capacity of fiber-reinforced cementitious composites (FRCC), has been frequently investigated using the three-point bending test, the four-point bending test, and the uniaxial tensile test, etc. (Barros and Sena-Cruz, 2001; Barragán et al., 2003; Zerguini and Rossi, 2003; Kazemi et al., 2007). Moreover, fracture energy of FRCC can also be estimated through theoretical methods. For instance, based on the derivation of relation between bridging stress provided by fibers on fracture plane and crack opening displacement (σ-w), fracture energy can be obtained by integrating the area under σ-w relation curve (Li et al., 1991; Jain and Wetherhold, 1992; Li, 1992; Lin and Li, 1997). Further, Jain and Wetherhold (1992), Masud and Kais Bin Zaman (2006) reported that on the basis of obtaining energy absorption of single fiber with arbitrary orientation and embedded length first, fracture energy of FRCC can also be well evaluated. However, prior publications concerning theoretical estimation on FRCC fracture energy all focused on fibers with straight shape; Li et al. (1991), Li (1992), Lin and Li (1997), Jain and Wetherhold (1992), and Masud and Kais Bin Zaman (2006). The corresponding theoretical fracture energy estimation on cementitious composites reinforced with deformed (steel) fibers, has so far been little reported.

Compared with straight steel fiber, deformed steel fibers usually have significantly better reinforcing effects on both mechanical properties and toughness of cementitious composites. Hooked-end steel fiber is one type of deformed steel fibers, which has been popularly used in both research labs and engineering practices. Moreover, due to its relatively simple fiber geometry consisting of a main shaft and hooks at both ends, research on reinforcing mechanism of hooked-end steel fiber in cementitious composites has attracted considerable attention. Nevertheless, most published literatures focused on the pullout behavior of single hooked-end steel fiber through experimental and theoretical methods (Banthia, 1990; Banthia and Trottier, 1994; Alwan and Naaman, 1999; Chanvillard, 1999; Sujivorakul et al., 2000; Dong and Li, 2004; Kim et al., 2008; Cunha et al., 2010). Modeling fracture behavior and fracture energy of hooked-end steel fiber-reinforced cementitious composite (HSFRCC) has been scarce, owing to significant difficulty caused by various hooked-end deformations of steel fibers intersecting a fracture plane of cementitious composite.

Specifically, when a HSFRCC member is fractured, hooked-end steel fibers intersecting a fracture plane will be pulled, and slide with their hooked-ends being totally deformed, partially deformed, or nondeformed. The pullout energy of steel fiber with deformed hooked-end and that with nondeformed hooked-end are significantly different (Cunha et al., 2010). Therefore, in order to develop a micromechanical fracture energy model of HSFRCC, we employ the following methodology. First, the energy dissipation mechanisms of hooked-end steel fiber with deformed and nondeformed hook-ends are investigated, and the corresponding pullout energies are theoretically derived. Probabilistic method is then utilized to account for energy contributions from all hooked-end steel fibers intersecting the fracture plane.

sec.title: PULLOUT ENERGY OF SINGLE HOOKED-END STEEL FIBER FROM CEMENTITIOUS MATRIX
Categories of Hooked-End Steel Fibers Intersecting the Fracture Plane
sec.p:
As exhibited in Figure 1, numerous bridging hooked-end steel fibers intersect the fracture plane of a cementitious composite. It can be observed from Figure 1 that some steel fibers are pulled out with their hooked-ends deformed, while others are with nondeformed hooked-ends. The deformation of steel fiber hooked-end depends on many factors, such as the fiber embedded length, the fiber inclination angle on the fracture plane, the strength of cementitious matrix around steel fiber, and so on (Marković, 2006). Moreover, the energy dissipation mechanisms for steel fiber with deformed hooked-end and that with nondeformed hooked-end are significantly different. Therefore, in order to investigate the corresponding underlying energy dissipation mechanisms, the hooked-end steel fibers intersecting the fracture plane of cementitious composites are classified into the following three categories, according to their different fiber embedded lengths. We assume that, for each hooked-end steel fiber, the fiber debonding and pullout process only take place on one side of the crack plane.
In Category I, the embedded length of the steel fiber active part (le) is in the range 0<le≤lh1. From the sketch of hooked-end steel fiber shown in Figure 1, it is found that a hooked-end steel fiber in Category I would never have its hooked-ends deformed during the entire fiber pullout process. Therefore, the pullout behavior of a hooked-end steel fiber in this category is same as that of a straight steel fiber.
In Category II, the fiber pullout exit point is located between points B and C, as depicted in Figure 1, and the corresponding embedded length of the active part is in the range lh1<le≤lh1+lh2. Owing to the low resistant force provided by the local cementitious matrix around, the hooked-end of steel fiber in this category is unlikely to be deformed.
In Category III, a steel fiber has its hooked-end totally embedded in the cementitious matrix with the embedded length in the range lh1+lh2<le≤Lf/2. Depending on the resistant force provided by the local cementitious matrix around, the hooked-end of a steel fiber in this category could either be deformed or nondeformed. Figure 1.
Hooked-end steel fibers on the crack plane of a cementitious composite and fiber geometry scheme.

sec.title: Pullout Energy of Single Hooked-End Steel Fiber in Categories I–III
The Pullout Energy of a Single Hooked-End Steel Fiber in Category I
sec.p: As mentioned previously, hooked-end steel fibers in this category have the same pullout behavior as that of straight steel fibers. Compared with the frictional pullout energy, the fiber debonding energy is small and negligible (Jain and Wetherhold, 1992). Hence, only frictional pullout process and energy are considered in this investigation. Assuming a constant frictional interface stress (τf) between the fiber and the cementitious matrix and ignoring the elastic fiber stretching at this stage, the relation between the fiber pullout force (P) and the displacement (δ) is expressed as (Li, 1992): (1) where k=efβ=24+f2(1+eπf/2) is the snubbing factor accounting for the snubbing effect that amplifies the pullout force (P) due to the inclination angle (β) by making analogy to an Euler friction pulley at the fiber exit point. Here, f in efβ is the snubbing coefficient, which is specific to a particular pairing of the fiber and the cementitious matrix. The value of f was experimentally determined to be in the range 0.5–1.0 for steel fiber (Li et al., 1990). df is the steel fiber diameter.
Based on Equation (1), the pullout energy of a single hooked-end steel fiber in Category I can be obtained by integrating the P-δ relation as follows: (2)

Particularly, when the frictional sliding displacement (δ) is equal to fiber embedded length (le), and fiber is totally pulled out of cementitious matrix, which is briefly expressed as δ=le=lh1, the pullout energy can be further written as (3) where the subscripts n and I in gnI1 and gnI2 refer to the nondeformed hooked-end and the hooked-end steel fibers in Category I, respectively; the numerical subscripts 1 and 2 refer to the general case and the particular case, respectively.

sec.title: The Pullout Energy of a Single Hooked-End Steel Fiber with Nondeformed Hooked-End in Categories II and III
sec.p:
Figure 2 schematically shows the pullout process of an aligned hooked-end steel fiber with nondeformed hooked-end in Category III. As shown in Figure 2, under stress concentration caused by the pullout force (P), the local matrix (BCDE) around the fiber embedded part is assumed to be fractured in shear failure mode (cf. Tian, 1998). Consideration of possible crushing failure contribution can be further investigated in future study. The corresponding fracture force provided by the local cementitious matrix around the embedded hooked-end steel fiber is written as (4) where the numerical subscript 3 in Frupt3 refers to a steel fiber in Category III; τcs the shear strength of the cementitious matrix; and α the hooked-end angle. Figure 2.
The pullout behavior of a hooked-end steel fiber with nondeformed hooked-end in Category III: (a) matrix weak zone, (b) fiber pullout with matrix fractured.

When a hooked-end steel fiber in Category II is aligned to the pullout force (P), the local small cementitious matrix could be fractured in modes of shear, bending, or combination of both. For simplicity, the shear failure mode is assumed for the steel fiber in Category II; the local cementitious matrix fracture force is thus expressed as (5) where the numerical subscript 2 in Frupt2 refers to the steel fiber in Category II.

When the local cementitious matrix is fractured, the steel fiber with nondeformed hooked-end in either Category II or III will continue undergoing frictional sliding with a distance of lh1 until it is totally pulled out of matrix. Further, on the basis of Equation (1) proposed by Li (1992), the corresponding P-δ relation can be generally expressed as (6) where cni is the calibration coefficient accounting for the fracture effect of local cementitious matrix. Using the condition of β = 0, δ=0, and Pmaxi=Frupti, cn2=Frupt2πdfτflh1 and cn3=Frupt3πdfτflh1 are obtained for hooked-end steel fibers with nondeformed hooked-ends in Categories II and III, respectively.
By integrating the P−δ relation of nondeformed hooked-end steel fiber in Category III, the pullout energy can be obtained as follows: (7)
Particularly, when δ=le=lh1, the pullout energy can be further written as (8)
Similarly, the pullout energy of a single steel fiber with nondeformed hooked-end in Category II can also be obtained as follows: (9)
Particularly, when δ=le=lh1, the pullout energy can also be written as (10)

sec.title: The Pullout Energy of a Single Steel Fiber with Deformed Hooked-End in Category III
sec.p:
The pullout energy of a steel fiber with deformed hooked-end in Category III consists of the frictional pullout energy and the deformation energy of steel fiber hooked-end. Moreover, the investigation of the corresponding pullout energy was recently carried out by Xu et al. (2010); see also Ju and Ko (2008), Ju, Ko and Ruan (2008), Ju, Ko and Zhang (2009), Ju and Yanase (2008, 2009), and Feng and Yu (2010). Therefore, only the key derivation results are summarized here.
When δ<le<lh1, frictional sliding energy (gdIII1) is expressed as (11)

In particular, when δ=le=lh1, frictional sliding energy (gdIII2) is expressed as (12)
The relations between the deformation energy (EP) of the steel fiber hooked-end and the frictional sliding displacement (δ) read (13) where Pmax-f=μσyπrf2cosϕ(2-μcosϕ)3cosα(1-μcosϕ)2+πτfdfle, and μ the Coulomb friction coefficient; rf the steel fiber radius; σy the yield stress of steel fiber; ϕ=(π-α)/2; ep1; and ep2 the plastic deformation energy of a unit length of hooked-end passing through hardened cementitious channel with the shape of hooked-end steel fiber. The detailed derivations and expressions of Pmax-f, ep1 and ep2 were recently reported in Xu et al. (2010).
Based on Equations (11), (12), and (13), the pullout energy of a single steel fiber with deformed hooked-end in Category III can be obtained using the superposition principle.

sec.title: MODEL DEVELOPMENT OF HSFRCC FRACTURE ENERGY
Model Assumptions
sec.p:
The following assumptions have been adopted to facilitate the micromechanical model development of fracture energy of HSFRCC.
The fracture plane of cementitious composite remains a plane.
A single crack dominates the progressive damage process. The phenomenon of multiple cracking is not taken into consideration in this investigation.
The hooked-end steel fibers in the cementitious matrix have 3D random distributions. Moreover, the embedded lengths of hooked-end steel fibers are uniformly distributed in the range 0-Lf/2.
The hooked-end steel fiber is sufficiently strong to ensure complete fiber pullout without fiber rupture.
The behavior of hooked-end steel fibers on the fracture plane is independent of each other. As aforementioned, the fiber debonding and pullout process only take place on one side of the crack, while the other part of the fiber remains intact. Therefore, the frictional sliding displacement (δ) in a single-fiber pullout test is equal to the composite crack opening displacement (w).
After full fiber debonding, the maximum fiber pullout force is assumed to be immediately achieved, since the hooked-end straightening mechanism is complicated.

sec.title: The Criterion for Hooked-End Deformation
sec.p: The criterion is established here for determining hooked-end deformation. The critical fiber embedded length (lce) is adopted as the key parameter in this criterion, which is a function of the matrix strength, the fiber length and diameter, the hooked-end geometry, etc.

Since the maximum pullout force (Pmax) of the hooked-end steel fiber is assumed to be achieved right after full fiber debonding, it can be assessed if the local cementitious matrix strength (Frupt3) is sufficiently strong to withstand the fiber maximum pullout force (Pmax). If positive, a hooked-end steel fiber in Category III will be pulled out with a deformed hooked-end; otherwise, the local cementitious matrix will be ruptured and the steel fiber will be pulled out with nondeformed hooked-end. Moreover, the critical condition of force equilibrium between the local cementitious matrix strength (Frupt3) and the maximum steel fiber pullout force (Pmax) is written as (14)
The maximum hooked-end steel fiber pullout force (Pmax) is obtained using the frictional pulley model proposed by Alwan et al. (1999), and expressed as (15)
Based on Equations (4), (14), and (15), the critical fiber embedded length (lce) takes the form: (16)

Based on Equation (16), the criterion for the hooked-end deformation is described as follows. If the embedded length (le) of the hooked-end steel fiber in Category III is no less than the critical fiber embedded length (lce), then the steel fiber will be pulled out from the cementitious matrix with deformed hooked-end; otherwise, the steel fiber will be pulled out with nondeformed hooked-end.

sec.title: Number of Bridging Hooked-End Steel Fibers on Fracture Plane
sec.p:
Figure 3 presents a hooked-end steel fiber intersecting the fracture plane of the cementitious matrix with the inclination angle (β) and distance (x) that is from the fiber centroid to the fracture plane. Since steel fibers in the cementitious matrix are assumed to be 3D randomly distributed, the probability density function of the inclination angle (β) is written as (17) where 0≤β≤π/2(Li et al., 1991). Figure 3.
The schematic plot of a hooked-end steel fiber on the fracture plane of the cementitious composite.

The uniform distribution of fiber embedded length (le) and the range of each fiber category is shown in Figure 4. As observed in Figure 4, the corresponding probability density function of fiber embedded length (le) reads (18) Figure 4.
The probability density function of fiber embedded length (le).

As reported by Wang et al. (1989), fibers may intersect the fracture plane; the fiber centroids are located at a distance of Lf/2 or less from either side of the crack plane. The total number of such fibers (Nt) takes the form: (19) where Ac is the area of the fracture plane; Af the cross-sectional area of the hooked-end steel fiber; and Vf the steel fiber volume fraction.

Moreover, the number of hooked-end steel fibers originally bridging the crack (N0) can be obtained by multiplying the total fiber number (Nt) expressed by Equation (19) with the probability of fibers actually intersecting the fracture plane (Wang et al., 1989; Li et al., 1991): (20)
Based on Figure 4 and Equation (20), the number of hooked-end steel fibers which are likely to have deformed hooked-ends takes the form: (21)

sec.title: Fracture Energy at Various Crack Opening Displacements (w)
sec.p:
The energy dissipation contributed by each fiber category at various crack opening displacements (w) will be systematically calculated on the basis of Equations (2), (3), (7)–(13) , (19), and (21).
The energy contributed by the hooked-end steel fibers in Category I intersecting the fracture plane:
• When the crack opening displacement (w) is in the range 0≤w<lh1, we write (22)

• When the crack opening displacement (w) is in the range w≥lh1, we have (23)
The energy contributed by the hooked-end steel fibers in Category II intersecting the fracture plane:

• When the crack opening displacement (w) is in the range 0 ≤ w ≤ lh1, we obtain (24) • When the crack opening displacement (w) is in the range w ≥ lh1, we arrive at (25)
The energy contributed by the hooked-end steel fibers with nondeformed hooked-ends in Category III intersecting the fracture plane:

• When the crack opening displacement (w) is in the range 0 ≤ w ≤ lh1, we have (26)
• When the crack opening displacement (w) is in the range w ≥ lh1, we obtain (27)
The energy contributed by the hooked-end steel fibers with deformed hooked-ends in Category III intersecting the fracture plane:
• When the crack opening displacement (w) is in the range w<lce, the frictional sliding energy (GdIII1) is obtained as (28)
• When the crack opening displacement (w) is in the range lce≤w≤Lf/2, the frictional sliding energy (GdIII2) is recast as (29) where Ff2=μσyπrf2cosϕ(3-μcosϕ)6cosα(1-μcosϕ)2 (Xu et al., 2010).
• When the crack opening displacement (w) is in the range 0≤w<lh1, the deformation energy (GPIII1) is obtained as (30)
• When the crack opening displacement (w) is in the range lh1≤w<lh1+lh2, the deformation energy (GPIII2) takes the expression (31)
• When the crack opening displacement (w) is in the range w≥lh1+lh2, the deformation energy (GPIII3) reads (32)
Based on Equations (26)–(32) , the energy dissipation contributed by the hooked-end steel fibers in Category III intersecting the fracture plane is summarized as (33)
Therefore, based on Equations (22)–(25) and (33), the fracture energy of HSFRCC at various crack opening displacements (w) is generally summarized as (34)

sec.title: COMPARISON OF MODEL PREDICTIONS WITH EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
Determination of Some Model Parameters
sec.p:
Figure 5 shows the scheme of direct tensile test on HSFRCC and the corresponding fracture energy calculation method. The fracture energy of HSFRCC at the crack opening displacement (wm) can be obtained by integrating σ-w relation which is expressed as (35) Figure 5.
The uniaxial tensile test on HSFRCC and the corresponding calculation method for fracture energy: (a) test setup, (b) fracture energy calculation.Barragán et al. (2003) and Zerguini and Rossi (2003) employed the uniaxial direct tensile test to investigate the σ − w relation of HSFRCC. Table 1 summarizes the related experimental material properties which include the compressive strength of normal concrete at 28 days (fcu), the hooked-end steel fiber length (Lf), the diameter (df), other physical properties, and specimen sizes used. Table 2 presents hooked-end geometric parameters (lh1, lh2, ρ1,ρ2, and α), the concrete shear strength (τcs), and the frictional sliding stress (τf). Since the values of hooked-end geometric properties in Table 2 were not reported by Barragán et al. (2003) and Zerguini and Rossi (2003), we estimate the relevant geometric properties by measuring the hooked-end steel fiber specimens with the same brands and fiber types reported. The concrete shear strength (τcs) and the frictional sliding stress (τf) are obtained from the concrete compressive strength (fcu) using empirical formulae (Oluokun, 1991; Mirsayah and Banthia, 2002). In particular, Mirsayah and Banthia (2002) suggested that the shear strength of normal concrete (τcs) could be related to its compressive strength by the following empirical relation: (36) Table 1.
Experimental material properties of hooked-end steel fibers and HSFRCC.

HSFRCC2 (Zerguini and Rossi, 2003) 50 200 1000 60 0.75 1.00 ϕ68 × 68 ϕ100 × 100
HSFRCC3 (Zerguini and Rossi, 2003) 90 200 1000 30 0.50 1.28 ϕ150 × 150
Table 2.
Geometric properties of steel fiber hooked-end and properties of cementitious matrix.
Series τcs (MPa) τf (MPa) lh1 (mm) lh2 (mm) ρ1 (mm) ρ2 (mm) α ϕ f
HSFRCC1 (Barragán et al., 2003) 6.1 2.2 2.78 2.62 3.44 3.62 π/4 3π/8 0.5 0.75 1.0
HSFRCC2 (Zerguini and Rossi, 2003) 7.8 3.1 2.78 2.62 3.44 3.62 π/4 3π/8
HSFRCC3 (Zerguini and Rossi, 2003) 10.5 4.7 1.3 1.24 3.22 3.16 π/4 3π/8

Neville (1996) recommended that the bond strength of concrete could be related to its tensile strength. Taha and Shrive (2001) took Neville’s recommendation and obtained the interfacial shear stress between carbon fiber and the concrete matrix using the following empirical formula (Oluokun, 1991): (37) where ft is the normal concrete tensile strength at 28 days.

Based on Equations (36) and (37), for simplicity, the shear stress of concrete (τcs) and the frictional sliding stress (τf) are obtained from the concrete compressive strength (fcu) displayed in Table 1. Since the value of snubbing coefficient (f) for a steel fiber in a cement-based matrix lies in the range 0.5–1.0 (Li et al., 1990), the f values considered in this investigation are taken as 0.5, 0.75, and 1.0, which are also presented in Table 2.

sec.title: Model Discussions
The Influence of Snubbing Coefficient (f)
sec.p:
Owing to the high variation of uniaxial tensile test, Barragán et al. (2003) used five specimens from the same mixture batch to obtain an average experimental result. Figure 6 illustrates the verification results between predicted and experimental fracture energies of HSFRCC. It can be observed from Figure 6 that, among the snubbing coefficients (f) of 0.5, 0.75, and 1.0, f = 0.5 shows the best agreement with experimental results when w = 1 and 2 mm. The fracture energies of HSFRCC are overestimated with increasing f. Therefore, f= 0.5 is adopted in the following discussions. Figure 6.
Validation of predicted fracture energies of HSFRCC under various crack opening displacements against available experimental data. Note: Specimen size of ϕ150 × 150 mm.

sec.title: The Influence of Specimen Sizes
sec.p:
Experimental fracture energy of concrete can be affected by specimen sizes used. The influence of specimen sizes was also carried out by both Barragán et al. (2003) and Zerguini and Rossi (2003), where specimen sizes included ϕ68 × 68, ϕ100 × 100, ϕ150 × 150, ϕ150 × 300, and ϕ150 × 450 mm. As exhibited in Figure 7, the predicted fracture energies are compared with available experimental results obtained from specimens with various sizes. When the crack opening displacement (w) is in the range 0.1–2 mm, the corresponding computed experimental fracture energies slightly differ from each other; good agreements are observed with the proposed fracture energy predictions. However, with the increase in the crack opening displacement (w = 3 mm), experimental fracture energy results evidently vary. The predicted fracture energies are higher than experimental results, but still show good agreements with that obtained from specimens with the size ϕ150 × 150 mm. Figure 7.
Validation of predicted fracture energies of HSFRCC against available experimental data obtained from specimens with various sizes.

sec.title: Experimental Verification of GF-w Relation
sec.p: Li et al. (1992) derived the constitutive σ-w relation for straight FRCC, and suggested that fracture energy at w=Lf/2 could be further obtained by integrating this relation. Following this methodology, the fracture energy of a straight steel fiber-reinforced cementitious composite (SSFRCC) with the crack opening displacement (w) is expressed as (38)

As illustrated in Figure 8, experimental results (Zerguini and Rossi, 2003) are employed for verifying the proposed fracture energy model and Equation (38). It is apparent that Equation (38) (based on Li et al., 1992) significantly underestimates the fracture energy of HSFRCC, indicating its inapplicability to HSFRCC. In Figure 8(a), the predictions by our proposed model show excellent agreements with experimental results in Zerguini and Rossi (2003) with fcu=50 MPa and Lf/df=80. In Figure 8(b), slight over-estimation is observed by the proposed fracture energy model with fcu=90 MPa and Lf/df=60. This slight over-estimation might be attributable to the scenario that during the fiber pullout process, some hooked-end steel fibers might rupture in the cementitious matrix with a high 28-day compressive strength of 90 MPa, causing noticeable energy release (Cunha et al., 2010). Therefore, steel fiber rupture should be further investigated in future research. Figure 8.
Experiment validation of the GF-w relation of HSFRCC: (a) HSFRCC2: fcu,28=50 MPa, Lf/df=80; (b) HSFRCC3:fcu,28=90 MPa, Lf/df=60.

sec.title: Potential Model Application
sec.p:
The main purpose of incorporating steel fibers into cementitious matrix is to increase the composite fracture toughness and post-peak ductility. The fracture energy of HSFRCC is considerably influenced by micromechanical fiber geometry, such as the fiber length (Lf), the fiber diameter (df), the hooked-end length (s),the hooked-end angle (α), etc. Optimal design on the micro-geometry of hooked-end steel fibers can significantly enhance the composite fracture toughness. In this study, we illustrate the potential applicability of the proposed methodology in facilitating optimal values of hooked-end steel fiber geometric parameters that result in maximum fracture energy. An example is presented as follows:
Prescribed known parameters are: the concrete compressive strength fcu=50 MPa at 28 days; the fiber length Lf=60 mm; the curvatures of hooked-end ρ1=3.44 mm; and ρ2=3.62 mm, respectively; the hooked-end angle α=π/4; Young’s modulus Ef=200 GPa; and the yield stress σy=1000 MPa.
Parameters to be determined are: the fiber diameter df; the fiber aspect ratio Lf/df; the hooked-end length s; and the hooked-end part lengths lh1 and lh2.

Based on the proposed model, a MATLAB code is run to assist the implementation of the optimal material design. By considering the influences of hooked-end steel fiber parameters (s,Lf/df,lh1/s) at the same time, the maximum fracture energies at hooked-end lengths of 4.00, 6.00, and 8.00 mm are obtained and summarized in Table 3. In general, higher fiber aspect ratio can better benefit the fracture property of SFRCC, which is consistent with the observation in Table 3. However, steel fibers with higher aspect ratios are generally more difficult to be dispersed in cementitious matrices by normal mixing, potentially downgrading the workability of fresh mixture and properties of hardened cementitious composites. Therefore, by considering both fiber aspect ratio and fracture energy listed in Table 3, the hooked-end steel fiber with Lf/df = 88.9, df=0.67 mm, lh1=2.04 mm, and lh2=3.96 mm would be considered to be the optimal setting, rather than the one with an obviously larger Lf/df of 120. Table 3.
The maximum theoretical fracture energies and the corresponding hooked-end steel fiber geometric properties.
Lf (mm) 60
α π/4
ρ1 (mm) 3.44
ρ2 (mm) 3.62
s (mm) 4.00 6.00 8.00 10.00
lh1/s 0.35 0.34 0.26 0.21
lh1 (mm) 1.40 2.04 2.08 2.10
lh2 (mm) 2.60 3.96 5.92 7.90
df (mm) 0.50 0.67 0.90 1.08
Lf/df 120.0 88.9 66.7 53.3
GPFmax (N/mm) 8.63 7.45 6.53 5.91

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: In this article, micromechanical fracture energy model of HSFRCC is systematically developed on the basis of the derivation of pullout energy of single hooked-end steel fiber and probabilistic calculation of bridging fibers on the crack plane. In the proposed model, fracture energy is a function of micromechanical parameters, such as the matrix strength, the frictional sliding stress between the cementitious matrix and steel fiber, the steel fiber yield strength, the fiber volume fraction, the fiber length and diameter, the hooked-end length, the hooked-end angle, and the curvatures of hooked-end curled parts. Predictions from the proposed model are compared with available experimental results from uniaxial tensile tests. Excellent agreements are observed in cases where we have the snubbing factor f=0.5, the specimen size of φ150×150 mm, and the cementitious matrix strength of 50 MPa, respectively. Owing to the close relationship between the fracture energy prediction and the hooked-end steel fiber micro-geometry, the proposed model can guide optimization of material behaviors and parameters by tailoring key hooked-end steel fiber micro-geometry.

fn.p: Figures 1–3 and 5–8 appear in color online: http://ijd.sagepub.com
